articles.name: Use Automatic Activation for the Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB)
articles.title: Use Automatic Activation for the Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB)
articles.body:
The automatic activation feature for the Gmail add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) allows admins to create a PAB instance for all Google Workspace users in their organization. With this feature, users will no longer have to manually activate their PAB with a license key, and magic mail will not be required for new users.

For more information about the Gmail add-on PAB, see our Gmail Add-on Phish Alert Button (PAB) Guide.

How to Enable Automatic Activation

To enable automatic activation for the Gmail add-on PAB, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click your email address in the top-right corner of the page and select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  4. From the Phish Alert menu, click the name of the desired PAB instance.
  5. In the Gmail Add-on Settings section, select the Enable Automatic PAB Activation check box.

Configure Automatic Activation

After you enable automatic activation, you will need to configure the feature for your users. The configuration process will vary depending on whether your users have used the Gmail add-on PAB previously.

To configure automatic activation for users who have not used the Gmail add-on PAB before, see the New Users subsection below. To configure automatic activation for users who have used the Gmail add-on PAB previously, see the Existing Users subsection below.

New Users

For new admins who have just enabled the Gmail add-on PAB for the first time, automatic activation will be the default for all your users. In this scenario, you and your users will not need to take any further action to configure automatic activation.

Back to top

Existing Users

The Gmail add-on PAB will continue to work for existing users who were manually activated. However, existing users who want to switch from manual activation to automatic activation will need to reset their PAB license. To reset your PAB license, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Gmail account.
  2. In your Gmail account, click the phish hook icon.
  3. Click the three dots icon in the Phish Alert modal.
  4. Click Reset License.
  5. Once your license is reset, refresh your web browser.

After refreshing the browser, your users’ Gmail add-on PAB should switch from manual activation to automatic activation.

Disable Automatic Activation

To disable automatic activation for your Gmail add-on PAB, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click your email address in the top-right corner of the page and select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  4. Click the name of your Phish Alert Button instance.
  5. In the Gmail Add-on Settings section, deselect the Enable Automatic PAB Activation check box.

Advanced Configuration Scenarios

The following scenarios address specific deployment configurations and organizational structures that may affect how you implement automatic activation.

Note:Automatic activation is unique per domain across all PAB instances and KSAT regions.

Multiple KSAT Regions

If your organization operates KSAT instances across different regions, such as the US, UK, CA, DE, and EU, you can only enable automatic activation for one PAB instance across all regions that share the same domain.

Example scenario:

Your organization has US and UK KSAT accounts that both use the @company.com domain. You must choose to enable automatic activation in either one PAB instance in your US account or one PAB instance in your UK account, but not both.

Multiple PAB Instances per KSAT Account

When using multiple PAB instances in a single KSAT account to customize messaging for different departments, only one instance can have automatic activation enabled for your domain.

We recommend you choose the PAB instance that serves your primary user base or most critical use case for automatic activation.

articles.name: Phish Alert Button (PAB) User Comments and Email Disposition Guide
articles.title: Phish Alert Button (PAB) User Comments and Email Disposition Guide
articles.body:
The User Comments and Email Disposition feature for the Phish Alert Button (PAB) allows your users to add comments and decide the disposition of an email when they use the PAB. This new feature can provide your IT security team with the reported email’s disposition as an early warning of possible phishing attacks or malicious emails. Then, your IT security team can then take effective action to prevent security or network compromise.

Note:The User Comments and Email Disposition feature is available for the EXE Phish Alert Button, Hybrid Phish Alert Button, Microsoft 365 (Outlook 2016 or above, Outlook Web Access), Microsoft Exchange (2013 or above), and Gmail Phish Alert Button (PAB) Add-on. This feature supports localized text entries.

Read the sections below to learn how to enable this feature, how this feature works, and how your users can use this feature in their inboxes.

Enabling User Comments and Email Disposition

To allow your users to send comments and decide the email’s disposition, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to your Account Settings screen. This screen will look different depending on your account version. For more information, see the Enable and Configure section of our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.
  2. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  3. Select the Enable Phish Alert check box.
  4. If a Phish Alert instance does not exist, click the green Add Phish Alert Instance button.
  5. Select the Allow users to leave comments and disposition check box.

Email Disposition

When your users click the PAB to report an email, the sidebar will include options to suggest the disposition of the email. The possible dispositions are Phishing or Suspicious, Spam or Junk, and Unknown. For more information about each of these dispositions, see the list below:

  • Phishing or Suspicious: These emails are sent by cybercriminals to entice you to click on a link or to give up personal or sensitive information.
  • Spam or Junk: These emails are typically sent from companies trying to sell your users a product or service.
  • Unknown: Your users can select this option if they are unsure whether an email is a phish or spam. This is the default setting.

You can change the dispositions that your users see by customizing the disposition labels and descriptions. To customize the dispositions, navigate to the Languages section of your Account Settings. Open the language drop-down menu for the language used for the PAB instance. Then, enter your preferred labels in the Phishing or Suspicious Label, Spam or Junk Label, and Unknown Label fields. To display the disposition descriptions to your users, turn on the toggles next to the disposition label fields. Then, you can replace the default description text with your preferred text in the description fields. When your users click the PAB, the sidebar will display the disposition options with your customized labels and descriptions.

Note:You can customize the existing dispositions, but you can’t create new dispositions. The PAB will recognize which default disposition corresponds to a customized disposition and provide that information when the email is forwarded to PhishER or your submission email.

You can also set different email addresses as recipients based on the disposition that your users select. For example, you can specify one email address to receive spam emails and another email address to receive emails that your users suspect are malicious. To set a recipient, enter email addresses in the fields under Send Dispositioned Email to.Users are not required to suggest a disposition when using the Phish Alert Button. For more information on the difference between phishing and spam emails, see our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Downloadable PDF File Guide.

User Comments

Your users can use the Add a comment section to tell your security team why they choose to classify the email as Phishing or Suspicious, Spam or Junk, or Unknown. This text box can be used to explain any potential red flags that your users noticed in the email. These comments can help your security team get a better understanding of what indicators they should look out for when reviewing the reported emails. Users are not required to add a comment when using the Phish Alert Button.

When your users submit user comments, you can either view the comments in PhishER or in the PAB notification emails. In the PAB notification emails, the user comments will be attached as a .json file and displayed in the User Comments section.

Note:PAB notification emails will be forwarded to the email addresses that are specified in the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: setting in your Account Settings. For more information about configuring PAB in your Account Settings, see the Enable and Configure PAB section of our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.

For information about viewing user comments in PhishER, see the PhishER Integration section below.

PhishER Integration

You can also view your users' suggested dispositions and comments in your PhishER platform. Using PhishER, you can further categorize suspicious emails and determine if these emails are legitimate.

In PhishER, the Phishing or Suspicious and Spam or Junk dispositions will appear as tags on individual emails. You can use these tags to separate your users' suggested dispositions from other tags in PhishER. The word User: will appear in front of the Phishing or Suspicious and Spam or Junk tags. No tag will appear for an email that is reported as Unknown.

You can view all user comments in the Discussions tab on the right side of the Message Details page. Each user comment will appear in the corresponding email, along with the user's name.

Microsoft Integration

If your organization uses Microsoft Defender for Office 365, you can send reported emails to Microsoft. If you enable both the User Comments and Email Disposition feature and the Enable Microsoft 365 Defender Integration feature, you can specify an email address for your Microsoft account’s Submissions page to receive reported emails with your users' suggested dispositions. For more information about this integration, see our Integrate Microsoft Defender for Office 365 with the Phish Alert Button (PAB).

Note:If you don’t enable the User Comments and Email Disposition feature, your users can only select the Phishing or Suspicious or Spam or Junk disposition.

User Experience

The User Comments and Email Disposition feature is compatible with the Hybrid PAB, Microsoft 365 (Outlook 2016 or above, Outlook Web Access), Microsoft Exchange (2013 or above), and with the Gmail PAB Add-on. When a user clicks on the Phish Alert Button to report an email, the Phish Alert sidebar will appear. Once your users select the email's disposition and add comments, they will click on the Phish Alert button to report the email.

articles.name: Partner and Multi-Account: Save and Send Reports
articles.title: Partner and Multi-Account: Save and Send Reports
articles.body:
Within our reporting feature, you can save reports from managed accounts to be viewed at a later time or send saved reports to other managed accounts. You can also choose to schedule reports to be generated and sent at a set frequency, such as every quarter. See below for more information on how to save and send reports.

Saving Reports

To save a report to be viewed at a later time, see the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click the Reports tab.
  3. Select a report that you would like to save and set your desired filters.
  4. Click View Report to generate the report with your desired filters.
  5. Click the Save Report button.

You can now add a name for the report and add the report to a category to keep your reports organized. The Default category is automatically added to all accounts, but you can create your own categories in the Saved Reports tab. Click the checkmark icon to save the report. All saved reports will stay in the Download Center for 90 days.

Note: If a user who created a saved or scheduled report is deleted from your KSAT console, the account admin will automatically be made the creator of the report.

Viewing Saved Reports

From the Saved Reports tab, you can view all of your saved reports. See the image below for more information on the Saved Reports tab.

  1. Filter your saved reports by the type of report, groups included in each report, or accounts included in each report.
  2. Use the Include Other Users' Reports toggle to see all saved reports for the account instead of just your saved reports.
  3. Use this field to search for any saved reports by the name of the report or type of report.
  4. Click + Add next to categories to create a new category. To move reports between categories, click the checkbox next to the report name and select a category for the report from the Move to Category drop-down menu.

For added functionality, click the arrow under Actions.

  1. Use these buttons to generate a PDF or CSV file in your Download Center.
  2. Click Send to redirect you to the New Scheduled Report window. See the Sending and Scheduling Reports section for more info.
  3. Click Clone to duplicate a saved report. Cloning creates a new saved report using the same information as the original saved report which can be modified at any time. You can give the cloned report a new name and category.

Sending and Scheduling Reports

To send reports to other users and generate reports on a schedule, see the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click the Reports tab.
  3. Select the Scheduled Reports tab.
  4. Click Send Report.

You can send any saved reports in the New Scheduled Report window. You can also access this window by clicking the Actions arrow in your Saved Reports tab and selecting Send. See the image below for details on the available fields.

  1. Name: The name that displays in the Scheduled Reports tab.
  2. Send to: Choose which Account Management Admins you want this report to be sent to.
  3. Frequency: Select how often you want a report to be sent to your users. Scheduling reports with a frequency of more than once will automatically generate reports on the specific date and time selected.
  4. Start Time: The date and time the report will be sent to your users.
  5. Saved Report: Select which specific report you want to send or schedule.
  6. Format: Choose the file type of the report that your users will receive.

Once the report has been sent, the recipients can view the report in the Download Center of their KSAT console. Any sent reports will stay in the Download Center for 90 days. You can disable scheduled reports from being sent at any time in the Scheduled Reports subtab.

An email will also be sent to all recipients notifying them about a report being shared along with a link to download the report. See the image below for an example of what the email will look like. They will be prompted to log in to their KSAT account and the report will download immediately on login.

Viewing Scheduled Reports

From the Scheduled Reports subtab, you can view all of your scheduled reports. See the image below for more information on how to navigate the Scheduled Reports tab.

  1. Filter your scheduled reports by the type of report or the accounts included in each report.
  2. Use the Include Other Users' Reports toggle to see all scheduled reports for the account instead of just your scheduled reports.
  3. Use this field to search for any scheduled reports by the name of the scheduled or saved report.
  4. Click Edit to modify the details of the scheduled report.
  5. Click Clone to replicate a scheduled report. Cloning will create a new scheduled report using the same information as the original scheduled report which can be modified at any time.
  6. Click Deactivate to set a report as inactive. The only way to reactivate a scheduled report is to clone it.
  7. See the Inactive tab for one-time reports that have previously run and deactivated recurring reports. Inactive scheduled reports will be automatically deleted after 90 days.
Note: If you choose to Send Now while the same report has a recurring schedule, the one-time report will not affect the recurring schedule.

For further assistance with this feature, please contact our support team and they would be happy to help.

articles.name: Customize Your Widgetized Dashboard
articles.title: Customize Your Widgetized Dashboard
articles.body:
From the Dashboard tab, you can monitor your organization's activity for the features that you use in your KnowBe4 account. If you have access to the widgetized dashboard feature, you can customize your default dashboard by adding, removing, resizing, and rearranging widgets. In addition to the default widgets, you can access more widgets so that you can customize your widgetized dashboard's display. For information about the default widgets that display on your dashboard, see our Dashboard article.

Note:The widgetized dashboard is only available for paid accounts that have access to both phishing and training. For more information, please contact your Customer Success Manager.

Additional Widgets

If you have access to the widgetized dashboard, you can add additional widgets to your dashboard. Depending on how you want to display your organization's information, you can use these widgets as an alternative to some of the default widgets. To learn how to add widgets to your dashboard, see the Adding Widgets section below.

Note:Depending on your security role, you may not have access to all widgets. The widgets that you are unable to access will appear grayed out. If you hover your mouse over a widget that is grayed out, a message will display that indicates that you do not have access to the widget. For more information, please contact your administrator.

See the list below to learn about the additional widgets that you can add to your dashboard.

  • Phish Alert Button Data: You can add the Phish Alert Button Data widget to view the number of times that your users have installed the PAB, uninstalled the PAB, reported a simulated phishing email with the PAB, and reported a non-simulated phishing email with the PAB. This widget can be used as an alternative to the full Phish Alert Button widget, which also includes a graph comparing your organization's phish alert reports.

  • Phishing Industry Benchmark Data: You can add the Phishing Industry Benchmark Data widget to compare your organization’s Account Average Phish-prone Percentage to an industry-specific Phish-prone Percentage. You can customize this data by changing the Industry, Organization Size, and Program Maturity from the drop-down menus. This widget can be used as an alternative to the full Phishing widget, which also includes a graph of your organization's phishing security test history.

  • Available Range: You can add the Available Range widget to view your organization’s current Risk Score on a scale that ranges from 0 to 100. You can use this widget as an alternative to the full Organization's Risk Score widget, which also includes a graph of your organization's risk score over time.

    Note:For more detailed insights into your organization’s Risk Score, see our SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score Guide.
  • SAPA Industry Benchmark Data: You can add the SAPA Industry Benchmark Data widget to compare your organization’s average Security Awareness Proficiency Assessment score to an industry-specific average. You can use this widget as an alternative to the full Security Awareness Proficiency Assessment (SAPA) widget, which also includes a graph breaking down the benchmark data by the SAPA knowledge area.

  • SCS Industry Benchmark Data: You can add the SCS Industry Benchmark Data widget to compare your organization’s average Security Culture Survey score to an industry-specific average. You can use this widget as an alternative to the full Security Culture Survey (SCS) widget, which also includes a graph breaking down the benchmark data by the SCS dimensions.

Adding Widgets

If your dashboard does not display all of the widgets that you need, you can add widgets to your dashboard. You can also add widgets back to your dashboard after you remove them.

Follow the instructions below to add a widget to your dashboard.

  1. Log in to your KSAT account.
  2. From the Dashboard tab, click the grid button to edit your dashboard.

  3. Click the Add Widget button.

  4. In the Add Dashboard Widget window, select one or more of the widgets that you want to add.
  5. Click the Add button.

  6. Click the Save button in the top-right corner of the page.

Removing Widgets

You can remove widgets from your dashboard to focus on the widgets that are most important to your organization. For example, if your organization is not using SAPA yet, you may want to remove the Security Awareness Proficiency Assessment (SAPA) widget from your dashboard until your organization begins using the assessment.

Follow the instructions below to remove a widget from your dashboard.

  1. Log in to your KSAT account.
  2. From the Dashboard tab, click the grid button to edit your dashboard.

  3. In the top-right corner of the widget, click the minus icon to remove the widget.

  4. Click the Save button in the top-right corner of the page.

Resizing Widgets

You can adjust the sizes of widgets to emphasize specific widgets, to fit widgets next to each other, or to organize widgets in a way that helps you understand your organization's data. For example, if you want to focus on your users' training progress more than how they are using the PAB, you can make the Training widget larger than the Phish Alert Button widget.

Follow the instructions below to resize a widget on your dashboard.

  1. Log in to your KSAT account.
  2. From the Dashboard tab, click the grid button to edit your dashboard.

  3. Hover your mouse over the bottom-right corner of the widget until you see the arrow icon.
  4. Click and drag inwards or outwards until the widget is your preferred size.

  5. Click the Save button in the top-right corner of the page.

Rearranging Widgets

You can move widgets to different areas of your dashboard to group features together or to monitor related data. For example, if you want to determine whether your organization's Phish-prone Percentage is causing the change in your organization's Risk Score, you can place the Phishing widget next to the Risk Score Scale widget.

Follow the instructions below to rearrange a widget on your dashboard.

  1. Log in to your KSAT account.
  2. From the Dashboard tab, click the grid button to edit your dashboard.

  3. Hover your mouse over the center of a widget until you see the crossed arrow icon.
  4. Click and drag the widget in any direction until the widget is at your preferred location.

  5. Click the Save button in the top-right corner of the page.
